kou commented on issue #6136: ARROW-7508 [C#] DateTime32 Reading is Broken
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6136#issuecomment-572337878
 
 
   Normally, we don't need to clean up commit history because our merge script squash commit history. But this commit history includes `#1` and `#2` in commit messages. It refers unrelated issues/pull requests. It's not good.
   
   I'll rebase this branch.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

eerhardt commented on issue #6136: ARROW-7508 [C#] DateTime32 Reading is Broken
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6136#issuecomment-572337997
 
 
   > why? 
   
   Because it clutters the history.
   
   > isnt that what squash merging takes care of?
   
   Squash merging will merge all those commits into a single commit, yes. But each of those commits makes an entry into the commit message. For example, take a look at the commit message of:
   
   https://github.com/apache/arrow/commit/7f905a61dec9c3c410f0a0f118e9a57c99b1bb75
   
   ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8291187/72029820-c6a7a400-324c-11ea-92ac-aeeb80dd8ef3.png)
   
   Notice that each commit that was in the original PR has an entry in that message.
   
   As-is right now, this PR would have 5 lines in the message for meaningless commits.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

eerhardt commented on pull request #6136: ARROW-7508: [C#] DateTime32 Reading is Broken
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6136#discussion_r364541307
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Arrays/Date32Array.cs
 ##########
 @@ -64,7 +64,7 @@ public Date32Array(ArrayData data)
                 return default;
             }
 
-            return DateTimeOffset.FromUnixTimeMilliseconds(value.Value * MillisecondsPerDay);
+            return DateTimeOffset.FromUnixTimeMilliseconds((long)value.Value * MillisecondsPerDay);
 
 Review comment:
   I wonder if it would be better to define `MillisecondsPerDay` as 
   
   ```C#
   private const long MillisecondsPerDay = 86_400_000;
   ```
   
   That way if we use it for anymore arithmetic/multiplication, it would automatically be long arithmetic. Thoughts?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

abbotware commented on pull request #6136: ARROW-7508: [C#] DateTime32 Reading is Broken
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6136#discussion_r364571471
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Arrays/Date32Array.cs
 ##########
 @@ -64,7 +64,7 @@ public Date32Array(ArrayData data)
                 return default;
             }
 
-            return DateTimeOffset.FromUnixTimeMilliseconds(value.Value * MillisecondsPerDay);
+            return DateTimeOffset.FromUnixTimeMilliseconds((long)value.Value * MillisecondsPerDay);
 
 Review comment:
   I thought of that - but then I think you have to cast away the long on the division side - albeit the long/long to int conversion overflow during division becomes more obvious that the (int * int) overflow in multiplication....  so it probably is best ti define the constant as long
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org
